webpage.para: This document covers how to get NetBSD in a number of different ways:

listitem.link: Browsing source code on the web

webpage.para: For more information about NetBSD releases see:

sect1.title: Formal Releases
sect1.para: The latest formal release is NetBSD &release.latest;.

These are intended to provide a stable, supported platform for use in production systems. The NetBSD-release branch can be considered an easy way to get the most up to date fixes for the most recent release.

sect1.title: NetBSD-current
sect1.para: The Release Engineering server runs nightly autobuilds for every port of -current. Generally these provide more features than formal releases, but have not had the same degree of testing, and should be avoided on production systems where possible. The release engineering server also has a web server with autobuild statistics. A list of mirror sites is also available.
The version is always in the form of N.99.M (eg: 3.99.23).

itemizedlist.listitem: Mirror sites, and other methods of downloading.

sect1.para: Release engineering FTP server (access via HTTP) and the release engineering webserver. A list of mirror sites is also available.
How to track the NetBSD-current via AnonCVS? via SUP? More information on NetBSD-current.

sect1.title: Browsing source code on the web

listitem.para: The cvsweb interface provides access to easily retrieve files or diffs of any version in the source repository without having to keep a checked-out copy around locally. A list of mirror sites is also available.
OpenGrok is an index of all functions, filenames, variables in NetBSD that can be used as a cross-reference of the full tree.
